definitions: cut or shape wood stone or other material using an axe or similar sharp tool
examples: The carpenter hewed the logs into rough planks
Ancient builders hewed massive stones for the temple walls

definitions: cast a magic spell on someone or something to cause harm or misfortune
examples: The witch threatened to hex anyone who crossed her
Some people believe bad luck comes from being hexed

definitions: spend the winter in a dormant state with lowered body temperature and metabolism
examples: Bears hibernate in caves during the cold winter months
Some computer systems hibernate to save power when not in use

definitions: make sudden involuntary sounds caused by spasms of the diaphragm and throat
examples: She started to hiccup after drinking her soda too quickly
The baby hiccupped adorably after finishing her bottle of milk

definitions: forcibly seize control of a vehicle aircraft or situation often using threats or violence
examples: Terrorists attempted to hijack the plane during the international flight
Someone tried to hijack our meeting with their personal agenda

definitions: walk for a long distance especially across country or in the mountains
increase something suddenly or by a large amount
examples: We plan to hike the mountain trail this weekend
They love to hike through national parks during summer
The company decided to hike prices by twenty percent
Landlords often hike rent when demand for housing increases

definitions: create difficulties that result in delay or prevent progress or achievement
examples: Heavy rain will hinder our progress on the construction project
Don't let fear hinder you from pursuing your dreams

definitions: depend entirely on a particular circumstance or factor for success or outcome
examples: The success of our plan hinges on getting approval today
Her entire future seemed to hinge on this job interview

definitions: fasten or tether with a rope knot or hook to something else
travel by getting free rides in passing vehicles from strangers
examples: He hitched the trailer to the back of his truck
We need to hitch the horses to the wagon post
She decided to hitch across the country during summer break
It's dangerous to hitch rides from strangers these days

definitions: store or put things away in groups or separate compartments like bees
examples: The company hived its data across multiple secure servers
Workers hived the products in different warehouse sections by category

definitions: accumulate and hide away large quantities of something valuable for future use
examples: Some people hoard food supplies in case of emergencies
The dragon hoarded gold and jewels in its mountain cave

definitions: deceive someone by making them believe something false is real or true
examples: Someone tried to hoax the newspaper with a fake celebrity story
Internet pranksters often hoax people with elaborate false stories online

definitions: leave an item with a pawnbroker as security for a loan
examples: He had to hock his guitar to pay the rent
Many people hock jewelry when they need quick cash

definitions: use a garden tool to break up soil and remove weeds
examples: She needs to hoe the vegetable garden before planting seeds
Farmers hoe their fields to keep weeds from choking crops

definitions: take or use more than one's fair share of something selfishly
examples: Don't hog the bathroom when others are waiting to use it
He tends to hog the conversation at every dinner party

definitions: raise or lift something heavy using ropes pulleys or special equipment
examples: Workers hoist steel beams into place using the construction crane
They had to hoist the piano through the window opening

definitions: shout out loudly often to get someone's attention or express emotion
examples: She had to holler over the noise of the crowd
Kids holler for their parents when they get scared

definitions: remove the inside part of something to create an empty space
examples: They hollow pumpkins to make jack-o'-lanterns for Halloween decorations
The artist hollowed the log to create a unique flower planter

definitions: hit a baseball that allows the batter to make a complete circuit of bases
examples: The player homered twice in yesterday's championship game against their rivals
She homered in her first at-bat of the new season

definitions: settle on and farm a piece of land given by the government
examples: Pioneer families would homestead on the western frontier lands
My great-grandparents decided to homestead in Montana during the 1800s

definitions: sharpen a blade or tool and refine a skill through careful practice
examples: The chef takes time to hone her knives every morning
Athletes hone their skills through years of dedicated training

definitions: fill something with holes or tunnels in a pattern like a bee's honeycomb
examples: Termites had honeycombed the wooden beams with their tunnels
Underground streams honeycomb the limestone cliffs creating numerous caves

definitions: take a vacation with one's new spouse immediately after getting married
examples: The couple plans to honeymoon in Hawaii for two weeks
They decided to honeymoon locally due to travel restrictions

definitions: show great respect or esteem for someone through words actions or ceremonies
examples: The school will honour its best teachers at the annual ceremony
We gather to honour those who served in the military

definitions: cover someone's head or something with a hood or hood-like covering
examples: The falconer will hood the bird to keep it calm
They hood prisoners during transport for security reasons

definitions: walk or go somewhere quickly on foot especially over a distance
examples: We had to hoof it to the station to catch our train
If the car breaks down we'll have to hoof it home

definitions: play basketball or shoot baskets through the hoop in practice
examples: The kids love to hoop at the neighborhood court after school
He hoops every weekend with friends at the local gym

definitions: make the characteristic cry of an owl or similar sound
laugh loudly showing great amusement at something funny
examples: Owls hoot in the forest during the quiet night hours
The train will hoot its horn at every railroad crossing
The audience hooted with laughter at the comedian's jokes
We all hooted when she told that hilarious story

definitions: clean carpets or floors using a vacuum cleaner to remove dirt
examples: She needs to hoover the living room before guests arrive
I hoover the carpets twice a week to keep them clean

definitions: move by jumping on one foot or with light jumping movements
make a quick trip especially by air to a nearby place
examples: Children love to hop on one foot during playground games
The rabbit will hop across the garden looking for food
We can hop over to Paris for the weekend vacation
Let's hop down to the store for some milk

definitions: spray water or liquid through a hose onto something or someone
examples: Please hose down the driveway to remove all the dirt
Firefighters hose burning buildings to extinguish the flames quickly

definitions: pursue or harass someone persistently and relentlessly to get something
examples: Reporters hound celebrities for exclusive interviews and private details
Debt collectors hound people with constant phone calls every day

definitions: remain suspended in the air in one place without moving
stay close to someone or something ready to act if needed
examples: Helicopters hover above the accident scene during rescue operations
Hummingbirds hover near flowers while feeding on sweet nectar
Parents tend to hover around their children at the playground
The waiter seemed to hover near our table constantly

definitions: make a long loud crying sound like a wolf or dog
cry out loudly in pain anger or extreme emotion
examples: Wolves howl at the moon on cold winter nights
The wind howls through the trees during the storm
The child began to howl after falling off her bike
Fans howl in protest when the referee makes bad calls

definitions: crowd together closely for warmth protection or to discuss something privately
examples: The team will huddle before each play to plan strategy
Penguins huddle together for warmth in the Antarctic cold

definitions: breathe heavily and loudly especially from physical exertion
blow air forcefully or show annoyance through heavy breathing
examples: Runners huff and puff after finishing the marathon race
The old steam engine huffed as it climbed the hill
She huffed in frustration when her computer crashed again
He tends to huff when things don't go his way

definitions: remove the outer covering or husk from seeds fruits or grains
examples: Workers hull strawberries before making jam in the factory
You need to hull the peas before cooking them tonight

definitions: sing a tune with closed lips producing a droning sound
make a low steady continuous sound like that of a bee
examples: She likes to hum her favorite songs while doing housework
Children often hum tunes they hear on television shows
The refrigerator hums quietly in the corner of the kitchen
Bees hum as they fly from flower to flower

definitions: cause someone to feel less important or proud often through defeat
examples: The defeat will humble even the most confident players
Life has a way to humble those who become too arrogant

definitions: make someone feel ashamed or foolish by injuring their dignity and pride
examples: The bully tried to humiliate him in front of everyone
Parents should never humiliate their children in public places

definitions: comply with the wishes or mood of someone to keep them happy
examples: Sometimes it's easier to humour him than to argue
The nurse knows how to humour difficult patients with kindness

definitions: carry or move something heavy with great effort over a distance
examples: Soldiers had to hump their gear across the desert terrain
We'll need to hump these boxes up three flights of stairs

definitions: bend one's back forward and raise the shoulders in a curved position
examples: Don't hunch over your computer screen while working all day
He tends to hunch his shoulders when feeling nervous or stressed

definitions: jump over barriers or obstacles while running in a race or movement
examples: Athletes hurdle over barriers in track and field competitions
The horse can hurdle fences with grace and powerful speed

definitions: throw something with great force in a particular direction
examples: Angry protesters hurl stones at the abandoned building windows
The pitcher can hurl fastballs at incredible speeds

definitions: make someone be quiet or stop making noise especially by saying hush
examples: The teacher had to hush the noisy students several times
Parents hush crying babies by rocking them gently

definitions: remove the dry outer covering from corn or other seeds
examples: Farm workers husk corn before sending it to the market
We need to husk these coconuts to get the meat inside

definitions: push or move someone roughly or hurriedly in a direction
work rapidly and energetically especially to make money
examples: Security guards hustle troublemakers out of the concert venue
Don't let anyone hustle you into making quick decisions
She hustles at two jobs to pay for college tuition
Street vendors hustle to sell their goods before sunset

definitions: breed or cause plants or animals to produce offspring of mixed varieties
examples: Scientists hybridize crops to create disease-resistant varieties
Gardeners often hybridize roses to develop new colors and forms
